headline.main: A Small Restaurant Gets a Big Increase in Health Premiums -- and Misses the Tax Credit

docs.abstract: The Herbfarm Restaurant seems like precisely the kind of small business that should benefit from the Affordable Care Act's tax credits.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bargaining committee’s recommendation to allow elimination of traditional pensions for new hires is a victory for the nation’s biggest military contractor.

headline.seo: Lockheed Contract Wins Approval of Union Bargainers
headline.main: Union Panel Urges Approval of Lockheed Contract
headline.print_headline: Union Panel Urges Approval of Lockheed Contract

docs.abstract: Bargaining committee for the union machinists on strike at Lockheed Martin's fighter jet plant in Fort Worth, Tex, recommends that members vote for a new contract that would eliminate traditional pensions for new hires; pension change is seen as a victory for the nation’s biggest military contractor.
docs.snippet: The bargaining committee’s recommendation to allow elimination of traditional pensions for new hires is a victory for the nation’s biggest military contractor.

docs.lead_paragraph: A review of the 6 hours, 14 minutes and 7 seconds of arguments in the case revealed an exceptionally garrulous and jocular bench.

headline.seo: Sidebar: A Look Back at Court’s Arguments on Health Care, Laugh Count Included
headline.main: A Look Back at Court’s Arguments on Health Care, Laugh Count Included
headline.print_headline: Reviewing the Health Care Arguments, Laugh Count Included

docs.abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column highlights a study by litigation consultant Ryan A Malphurs and University of North Texas graduate student L Hailey Drescher of the arguments in the Supreme Court case on the health care reform law, which found that the bench was exceptionally garrulous and jocular; the study reflects the work of a court that takes a distinctively loose and even lighthearted approach to adjudication, one its decisions generally mask.
docs.snippet: A review of the 6 hours, 14 minutes and 7 seconds of arguments in the case revealed an exceptionally garrulous and jocular bench.

headline.main: How Wider Coverage Affects Health Spending

docs.abstract: Readers weigh in on an Oregon study that found a group of newly insured people were happier, but also incurred more medical expenses than uninsured people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many governmental entities across the nation are looking at new money-raising strategies to keep from cutting services.

headline.seo: Cities Consider Selling Ads as Economic Lifelines
headline.main: Your Ad Here, on a Fire Truck? Broke Cities Sell Naming Rights
headline.print_headline: Your Ad Here, on a Fire Truck? Broke Cities Sell Naming Rights

docs.abstract: Dozens of financially struggling cities, transit systems, and school districts around the country are trying to weather the economic downturn by selling advertisements, naming rights and sponsorships to raise money; such naming deals have grown more popular with advertisers as they try to reach consumers who have grown more adept at tuning out traditional commercials, whether with remote controls or digital video recorders.
docs.snippet: Many governmental entities across the nation are looking at new money-raising strategies to keep from cutting services.

docs.lead_paragraph: The impending decision by the Supreme Court on President Obama’s health care law will be the beginning of the end of one of the most divisive policy battles in decades.

headline.sub: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling
headline.print_headline: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling
headline.seo: Washington Memo: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling
headline.main: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling

docs.abstract: Members of Congress, health care lobbyists, campaign officials and thousands of lawyers who populate Washington, DC, are waiting for the Supreme Court ruling on President Obama's health care law with trepidation and all-consuming intensity; coming at the crest of a contentious presidential campaign, it will be the beginning of the end of one of the most divisive policy battles in decades, one that helped set off the Tea Party movement and became the central conflict in the raging political war between Republicans and Democrats.
docs.snippet: The impending decision by the Supreme Court on President Obama’s health care law will be the beginning of the end of one of the most divisive policy battles in decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rarely have the black-robed justices at the Supreme Court held so much potential for dominating the political conversation. This week, the court is expected to rule on two politically explosive issues that could shape the contours of the presidential and Congressional campaigns over the next five months.

headline.main: Preparing to Respond To Landmark Decisions

docs.abstract: Caucus column; the Supreme Court's impending decisions on Arizona's immigration law and the Affordable Care Act, coming just as the 2012 elections heat up, will exert a strong political influence; candidates, interest groups and media figures are preparing their responses to the potential outcomes. (M)
